captions.text:
What is that
which gives me joy?
A man stands alone at a plate.

This is the time for what?
( <i>guests murmur responses</i> )

Looks, throws, catches, hustles.
Part of one big team.

Bats himself the livelong day,
babe ruth, ty cobb and so on.

Sunny day, the stands
are full of fans.
What does he have to say?

I'm going out there
for myself.

comments.author: Holy Moses

comments.text:
This was based on a real (and bloodier) event. It involved the murders of 
three men– John Scalise, Albert Anselmi and Joseph Giunta. Their plan was 
to assassinate Capone and seize his crime empire. Unfortunately for them, 
Capone found out via a loyal intermediary. He threw a gala dinner in their 
honor in Hammond, IN. After they were engorged with food and sated with 
wine, Capone henchmen jumped them on a prearranged signal and tied them to 
their chairs. Screaming furiously, Capone produced the bat and beat the 
three almost to death; they were each finished off with a gunshot to the 
head. Their bodies were left on a deserted stretch of road outside of town.﻿

comments.author: Ariel Goldfarb

comments.text:
De Niro's grip is entirely wrong. This surprises me since De Niro is known 
to be a method actor. In fact, he is ordinarily so fastidious about this 
that for the Untouchables he actually insisted that his wardrobe include 
silk underwear because that is what Al Capone wore in his prime. However, 
De Niro, here, apparently, neglected to interview top batters in baseball 
as well as some gangsters who have actually used bats in their chosen 
profession. Had he done this, this would have led to a more authentic 
rendering of the "baseball" hit job.﻿
comments.author: Ralph Adamo

comments.text:
+Ralph Adamo what does it fucking matter if he is holding it wrong when the

regardless of how you hold it.

P.S. seen your follow up comment. nvmnd
comments.author: Victor Katilis

comments.author: The 5th

comments.text:
Hey, lighten up. For the record, I was just making a joke about method 
acting, and wasn't criticizing De Niro's acting in the movie at all. And it 
wouldn't have mattered whether De Niro used a proper batter's grip or not 
because what's important is what Al Capone would have used. Although 
Capone's face bore a slight resemblance to Babe Ruth's, the baseball 
comparisons end there and Capone didn't have much knowledge of baseball 
grips and such either. Capone would have used the grip that would have 
"done the job," just as De Niro used in the movie.

I should also point out that the story of Capone and the use of a baseball 
bat at a dinner actually involved Tony Accardo striking three individuals 
at the table who Capone determined were traitors. According to the 
story, Accardo didn't kill actually them from the blows, and they were 
finished off by gunshots from Capone's assistants. I believe that Capone 
gave Accardo the nickname "Joe Batters"--although most used the nickname 
"Big Tuna" for Tony, as I don't think Tony like the "Batters" nickname. 
Tony Accardo went on to become the Boss in Chicago--where he maintained a 
much lower key presence than the Chicago bosses before or since. And while 
ruthless, he ruled with remarkable business acumen. Of course, history 
mostly "remembers" the flashy Dons, and not the brilliant low key ones like 
Tony Accardo.
comments.author: Ralph Adamo

comments.text:
he was probably more concerned with delivering one of the most memorable 
scenes in cinematic history. everyone who has ever seen this movie, 
remembers this scene and no one looks at his grip...besides, he wasn't 
playing a baseball player but Al Capone. I didn't know AC was such a 
prolific batter in his day.

comments.author: Blood Beryl

comments.text:
No.  He was in charge of Capone's bootleg liquor business in Chicago.  He 
allowed Elliot Ness and his buddies to break in and stop the shipments.  
The whole warehouse full of stock was impounded and destroyed, and all the 
workers were arrested and presumably put in jail.  In short, Ness declared 
war on Capone and this guy (who got wacked), let it happen.  Bad day for 
this guy.

comments.text:
You know Al Capone had a good side too.  Every soup kitchen in Chicago that 
fed the poor was financed by Al.  Also when he was on trial there was a 
disabled Veteran selling apples from a cart outside the courthouse.  Each 
day when Al walked by the Veteran Al gave him a least $10.00.  Although 
there were those that hated him he also had many disciples that were 
recipients of his kindness and generosity.  RIP Al  ﻿

comments.author: Interestingenough4

comments.text:
In the mob business when you're called to a meeting you go even if you know 
you're gonna get whacked. It's like, if you show up, show your face and 
stand up to the situation they might give you a pass or just quickly whack 
you and take care of your family financially. If you don't show up they'll 
hunt everyone you fucking know and kill your family if they have to until 
they catch you, then they'll torture the shit out of you until you finally 
get whacked.
comments.author: Iosif I

comments.text:
That dude was totally fucked either way. But I think Capone would have 
given the table a new paint job with any of those guys if they had the 
balls to interrupt his spiel. The scene accurately depicted his 
psychopathy. Ideally, he would have clipped that guy in private but he was 
probably at boiling point anyway because of his incompetence. 

Simultaneously it was cathartic, time-saving and an example-setter
